data.text: The annually recurring date of a past event, as of personal or historical importance.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: a wedding anniversary; the anniversary of the founding of Rome.

data.text: A date that follows a certain event by a specified amount of time.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: his six-month anniversary of quitting smoking.

data.text: An event at which an anniversary is celebrated.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Returning with the revolution of the year; annual; yearly: as, an anniversary feast.
In the University of Cambridge, commemoration-day, an occasion upon which degrees are conferred since the disuse of the acts. See <internalXref urlencoded="act">act</internalXref>, n., 5.

The annually recurring date of some past event; more generally, a day set apart in each year for some commemorative observance; a day for the annual celebration of some notable event, public or private.
In the Roman Catholic Church, the yearly commemoration of the day of a person's death, by a mass offered for his soul, or such commemoration of his death daily for a year.
The act of celebrating a day on its annual recurrence; a yearly commemoration, or (rarely) something done or prepared for such commemoration.
The annual return of the day on which any notable event took place, or is wont to be celebrated.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.
examples: the <ex>anniversary</ex> of the Declaration of Independence

data.text: The day on which Mass is said yearly for the soul of a deceased person; the commemoration of some sacred event, as the dedication of a church or the consecration of a pope.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.
